After 22 years of playing one of cinema's most popular characters, The Tramp, comedian Charlie Chaplin decided to hang up the cane, the worn hat and the over-sized shoes. The Tramp's swan song was February 1936's "Modern Times," which happened to also be Chaplin's final silent film (accompanied by a musical and sound effects soundtrack).

After his 1931 "City Lights," Chaplin gave serious thought of producing his first Tramp film with dialogue. In fact, he had written a script with words coming out of his silent character's mouth. But during the early rehearsals for "Modern Times" he realized The Tramp should forever be destined as the quiet one in a crowd full of loud voices. Consequently, "Modern Times" emerged as a non-dialogue film, marking the end of the era of silent films-save for a few parodies such as the 2012 Academy Awards Best Picture "The Artist" and avant garde flicks.

On a European tour after the release of "City Lights," Chaplin was struck by the poverty he witnessed, brought on by the Great Depression. During a conversation with India's Mahatma Gandhi, the topic on factory machinery came up. Gandhi complained machines were making life difficult for the masses. Chaplin countered there was some benefits to those automated engines, but the profiteers overseeing the industry was the cause for such misery. The comedian/writer/director developed from that discussion what he called "a satire on certain phases of our industrial life." Not only is the factory system criticized in "Modern Times," but other critiques are offered on incarceration in prison, menial restaurant work, and other livelihoods whose cruel 'bosses' make life miserable for those trying to make ends meet.

To retain the look of silent movies, Chaplin shot "Modern Times" at 18 frames per second, a common rate in silents, versus the 24 frames required for sound. This explains the rapid movements of the characters when projected at the 24 frame rate, especially during the hilarious scenes. Chaplin dug in the past from his earlier movies to mimic several highlighted sequences, such as 1916's "The Rink." The Tramp roller skates blindfolded, twirling away on the upper floors of a department store, dangerously close to the outer edge without any railings. The scene, taking eight days to shoot, used trick photography with a the lower floor painted on a matted glass plate placed to one side of the camera lens to show the seemingly dangerous heights. But in reality he was simply skating on a flat surface. In another scene inside the same department store, the comic has a battle with the escalator, similar to his 1916 "The Floorwalker." Paulette Goddard, a Goldwyn Girl dancer, was marking time in Hollywood with uncredited roles when she met Chaplin, 13 years her senior. As the homeless 'Gamin' in "Modern Times," Goddard drew positive reviews as the stereotypical 'down on her luck' women Chaplin repeatedly peppered his films with, such as 1928's "The Circus" and 1931's "City Lights." The pair's two-year relationship was strained during the filming of "Modern Times" because of Chaplin's famous obsession to his work, devoting up to 18 hours a day while sleeping on a studio cot. Playing a homeless woman, Goddard was required to appear daily on the set with dirty clothes and no make-up. So tired of the filthy routine, Goddard showed up one day on the set with her hair washed and combed. Angry she appeared out of character, Chaplin fetched a bucket of water and dumped it over her head.

Some of Chaplin's most iconic shots are seen in "Modern Times." As a factory worker, The Tramp has trouble catching up to his task of tightening the widgets on an assembly belt. He jumps on the conveyor to continue his tightening, only to be sucked up into the machine and its gears. The construction crew built steel-looking gears in wood and rubber, but its filming still pained Chaplin as his body unnaturally bent through the mechanism. He planned to go through the process only once, and a reverse shot in post-production showed him being extracted. Another laborious sequence to film showed the Tramp testing out a time-saving device to enable the employees to continue their assembly line work while eating lunch. The corn-on-the-cob eating experiment goes haywire, sending corn kernels everywhere. Filming took seven days before Chaplin was satisfied.

"Modern Times," like all of Chaplin films, was a highly anticipated event that didn't disappoint the critics. Film Daily said "Chaplin has scored one of his greatest triumphs." Chaplin's biographer Jeffrey Vance wrote the movie, "remains one of Chaplin's greatest and most enduring works. Perhaps more important, it is the Tramp's finale, a tribute to Chaplin's most beloved character and the silent-film era he commanded for a generation." Film reviewer Ed Howard concludes, "Romantic, hilarious, beautiful, and endlessly inventive, Modern Times is one of Chaplin's greatest works, an ode to the irrepressible human spirit and its capacity for love and invention." The American Film Institute ranks "Modern Times" as the 78th Best Movie Ever and the 33rd Funniest Film. The Village Voice named The Tramp's last hurrah as the 62nd Best Film of the 20th Century while the BBC listed it as the 12th Greatest Comedy of All Time. The Chaplin film is included in the '1001 Movies you Must See Before You Die' book.

Made in 1936 between "City Lights" (1931) and "The Great Dictator" (1940), Chaplin's "Modern Times" (1936), much like Lang's "Metropolis" (1927) before and Tati's "Playtime" (1967) after, depicts a society whose fabric is largely built on technology that does not liberate, instead enslaves. In Lang the society is infected and fallen, dystopic, but in Chaplin and Tati the society itself seems to be largely unaware of its mechanics, which adds a tragic dimension.

In this sense Chaplin and Tati after him are more concerned with the individual's, the outsider's, perception of a world to which the general population seems to be oblivious to. That something's wrong is felt to the core by the poor workers within the factories in this film. It's this hopelessness that leads the Tramp to excel in Vigoan anarchism.

Some of the jokes are iconic in their visual creativity, others make use of sound quite brilliantly. What is surprising is how Chaplin takes many of the jokes to their extremes, as the visual gag of the lunch machine plays far too long for my taste, just as the scene with the lady on the bench.

This might summarize this film for me: on one hand wildly creative, on the other unexpectedly prolix, perhaps because of its self-awareness.

Chaplin's sentimental politics and peerless comic invention dovetailed more perfectly in this film than in any other he made. Charlie Chaplin finally got around to acknowledging the 20th century in this 1936 film, which substitutes machine-age gags for the fading Victoriana of his other work. Part satire, part slapstick comedy, part melodrama; the great pioneer of film, Charles Chaplin, has created his own monument with this film.
